docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials announced today that an experimental drug had markedly improved the health of a group of AIDS patients, adding months to the lives of some. They said thousands of victims of the deadly disease would soon be given access to the drug. The antiviral drug, azidothymidine, holds ''great promise for prolonging life for certain patients with AIDS,'' said Dr. Robert E. Windom, the Assistant Secretary for Health. The announcement today provided the first beam of hope in the battle against acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The drug, manufactured by the Burroughs Wellcome Company and also known as AZT, is the first to show effectiveness against the fatal disorder in controlled scientific studies.

headline.main: AIDS TEST DRUG PROLONGS LIVES IN SOME CASES

byline.original: By ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: THE establishment of the Nutritional Effects Foundation was formally announced in Washington on Monday. The creation of the three-month-old nonprofit private research and education organization, set up to promote production of lean meat raised with a minimum of drugs and chemicals, marks a change in the meat industry's attitude toward consumer demands for a leaner, safer product. Foundation directors will develop standards and a compliance system for the fat content of meats as well as for restrictions on the use of drugs and chemicals. Ten years ago, when Dietary Goals for the United States first recommended a switch from fat to lean meat for health reasons, the beef industry responded by trying to have the guidelines amended. But after a decade of watching beef consumption drop from 94.4 pounds per capita to 79.1 pounds, the industry has come to realize that the battle has been lost.

headline.main: NEW PANEL GRADING FAT CONTENT OF MEAT

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Federal Government urges schools across the country to adopt drug education programs from kindergarten through high school, many social scientists say that so far, few programs have worked. In fact, these researchers say, studies show some school programs that supply detailed information on drugs - a type of program that was used in New York City schools in the early 1970's - may actually lead to increased drug use among curious teen-agers. ''What we've been doing for the last 20 or 30 years is to try make to people aware of the dangers and scare them away from drugs,'' said an associate professor of psychology at Cornell University Medical College, Dr. Gilbert J. Botvin. ''Research shows those programs just have not worked.'' The researchers, who have reviewed more than 100 studies of school programs in the last 15 years, say they are encouraged by some newer efforts that teach students how to resist the influences of peers, family and the media.
